docs.snippet: British views on the duration and nature of the conflict with Argentina will change drastically if it proves true, as reported here, that Buenos Aires is receiving Gabriel missiles and additional Mirage and Dagger fighter-bombers and Exocet...
docs.lead_paragraph: British views on the duration and nature of the conflict with Argentina will change drastically if it proves true, as reported here, that Buenos Aires is receiving Gabriel missiles and additional Mirage and Dagger fighter-bombers and Exocet air-tosurface missiles. In that event, British analysts said, the expected elimination of Argentine military power on the Falkland Islands would not end the conflict but would usher in a period of hit-and-run warfare by air and sea in which the islands' British garrison and supply lines would be under constant attack. Although British officials do not believe that additional weapons can prevent an eventual British victory in the war, they fear that their delivery to Argentina would insure continuation of the conflict. Strikes by Argentine aircraft armed with Gabriel or Exocet missiles from bases on the mainland, one official said, might force London to reconsider the question of British air attacks on bases in Argentina. Such attacks are now forbidden.

headline.main: BRITISH SAY NEW ARMS FOR ARGENTINA WOULD MEAN LONG, HIT-AND-RUN WAR

byline.original: By DREW MIDDLETON, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina said today that its planes and artillery bombarded British positions surrounding the besieged Falkland Islands' garrison at Stanley.   The fighting was otherwise minimal in what one military spokesman said was ''the calm before the great...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina said today that its planes and artillery bombarded British positions surrounding the besieged Falkland Islands' garrison at Stanley. The fighting was otherwise minimal in what one military spokesman said was ''the calm before the great battle.'' Senior Argentine military officers said they expected the British to launch a major assault on the more than 7,000-man garrison at any moment. The joint military command said in a communique this afternoon that Argentine planes continued their nightly bombing runs in an ''offensive reconnaissance'' of British emplacements early this morning. The raids were most likely carried out by the air force's squadron of nine Canberra light tactical bombers, military officers said.

headline.main: ARGENTINES EXPECT ASSAULT BY THE BRITISH AT ANY TIME

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: South American leaders are already taking steps and anxiously pondering others to adjust to the conditions they believe will face the continent in the aftermath of the Falkland Island crisis.   The principal perception motivating them is that the...
docs.lead_paragraph: South American leaders are already taking steps and anxiously pondering others to adjust to the conditions they believe will face the continent in the aftermath of the Falkland Island crisis. The principal perception motivating them is that the United States can no longer be trusted as a fully reliable ally and that they must strengthen their own defenses and build more regional cooperation as a result. That feeling appears to have enough force to survive any outcome. An Argentine defeat would almost certainly serve to broaden the effects of the war on the area.

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina sought to keep an optimistic tone today as it awaited a British assault against Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands.   There was no confirmation here of reports by correspondents with British forces that the British had seized high...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina sought to keep an optimistic tone today as it awaited a British assault against Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands. There was no confirmation here of reports by correspondents with British forces that the British had seized high ground north of the Stanley airfield cutting off supply to the Argentines. A communique tonight said that the Argentines had battled British troops near Mount Kent, west of Stanley, forcing them to abandon equipment, and that an incursion by British Harrier jets had been repelled. Tonight's communique was similar to one issued this morning, which said reconnaissance forces had battled British troops west of Stanley, forcing them to ''retreat, abandoning equipment that proved the presence of troops from the 42d Commando Unit of the Marine Infantry.'' It said Argentine troops had ''observed enemy vehicles bogged down and without occupants in the zone of Mount Fitzroy.''

headline.main: ARGENTINA REPORTS RETREAT BY BRITISH IN CLASH

docs.snippet: A goal by Steve Hunt in the 34th minute gave the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over A.C. Milan of Italy in an international soccer match tonight before a crowd of 17,896 at Giants Stadium.   Hunt's goal after a corner kick by Vlado Bogicevic and a pass by...
docs.lead_paragraph: A goal by Steve Hunt in the 34th minute gave the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over A.C. Milan of Italy in an international soccer match tonight before a crowd of 17,896 at Giants Stadium. Hunt's goal after a corner kick by Vlado Bogicevic and a pass by Giorgio Chinaglia helped the Cosmos stay undefeated in international matches at the Meadowlands this year.

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: News of the British attack on Stanley reached here on a sparkling fall morning with Argentines in the streets of their capital celebrating the presence of Pope John Paul II.   The Pope was addressing an outdoor mass with more than a million people in...
docs.lead_paragraph: News of the British attack on Stanley reached here on a sparkling fall morning with Argentines in the streets of their capital celebrating the presence of Pope John Paul II. The Pope was addressing an outdoor mass with more than a million people in the congregation and an enormous banner in their midst with the single word ''Paz.'' Chants of ''We want peace!'' swept repeatedly across the multitude. There was no indication the Pope or his joyful listeners knew of the fighting in the Falklands, but for the millions of other Argentines following the papal visit on television, the intrusion of war into the celebration of peace was stark.

headline.kicker: JOHN PAUL PREACHES PEACE TO THE ARGENTINES, BUT SUDDENLY THE WAR

byline.original: By WARREN HOGE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The World Cup tournament begins today in Barcelona, Spain. The interest of an estimated 1.5 billion people will be focused upon the 24 teams competing in Spain from now through July 11.   Carlos Alberto and Giorgio Chinaglia of the Cosmos know what...
docs.lead_paragraph: The World Cup tournament begins today in Barcelona, Spain. The interest of an estimated 1.5 billion people will be focused upon the 24 teams competing in Spain from now through July 11. Carlos Alberto and Giorgio Chinaglia of the Cosmos know what it feels like to be in the World Cup tournament. Alberto, the sweeper, is one of the finest defenders in soccer history. He was captain of the Brazilian team in 1970. Chinaglia, the striker, played for the Italian national team that was eliminated in the first round in 1974.

headline.main: WORLD CUP: PRESSURES OF PLAYING FOR YOUR COUNTRY

docs.snippet: Sixty British troops wounded in fighting in the Falkland Islands left Montevideo for home today on board a Royal Air Force ambulance plane after arriving a few hours earlier on a hospital ship.   The Herald, a converted oceanographic survey ship, put...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sixty British troops wounded in fighting in the Falkland Islands left Montevideo for home today on board a Royal Air Force ambulance plane after arriving a few hours earlier on a hospital ship. The Herald, a converted oceanographic survey ship, put ashore 33 walking wounded and 27 stretcher cases who were immediately transferred to a waiting VC-10 jet. A British Embassy spokesman said two more hospital ships, each carrying about 60 wounded, were due to arrive in the Uruguayan capital next week.

headline.main: 60 Wounded British Soldiers Are Evacuated From Uruguay

docs.snippet: Argentina said tonight that its planes and ground forces repulsed a renewed British assault today west of the Falkland Islands' capital of Stanley in heavy fighting.   The military command said in a communique that casulties were high. It said...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina said tonight that its planes and ground forces repulsed a renewed British assault today west of the Falkland Islands' capital of Stanley in heavy fighting. The military command said in a communique that casulties were high. It said Argentine planes had prevented the British from evacuating their wounded from the battlefield with helicopters. The command said Argentine planes pounded British positions on Two Sisters Hills, nine miles west of Stanley, which were won in bitter fighting Saturday. It said Argentine artillery batteries dueled British guns firing from Mount Harriet, a nearby hill that was also captured Saturday.

headline.main: ARGENTINA ASSERTS IT HELD OFF DRIVE

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Argentina said tonight that British forces attacked and surrounded an Argentine scientific survey station in the South Sandwich Islands. The islands are a British dependancy of the Falkland Islands.   The Foreign Ministry said in a statement that...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina said tonight that British forces attacked and surrounded an Argentine scientific survey station in the South Sandwich Islands. The islands are a British dependancy of the Falkland Islands. The Foreign Ministry said in a statement that British helicopters today fired on the station, situated on the tiny island of Thule, one of the southernmost islands in the group, which lies more than 1,000 miles southeast of the Argentine coast in the South Atlantic. The attack would be the first hostile action in the area since Argentina seized the Falkland Islands 11 weeks ago. Britain completed the recapture of the Falklands on Monday when Argentine troops there surrendered.

headline.main: BRITISH REPORTEDLY LAND ON SOUTH SANDWICH ISLANDS

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times
